doc.title: John de Mol and Silvio Berlusconi buy Endemol
doc.author: Chris Tryhorn
doc.description: 1.15pm update: Endemol is to be sold for €3.5bn to a consortium backed by John de Mol and Silvio Berlusconi. By Chris Tryhorn.
doc.tags: Independent production companies,Business,Media,Media business,Television industry,Silvio Berlusconi,Endemol

main.p: Big Brother producer Endemol is to be sold for €3.5bn (£2.4bn) to a consortium including the group's co-founder John de Mol and former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi.
Spanish telecoms giant Telefonica said today it had agreed to sell its 75% stake in Endemol to the consortium for €2.63bn (£1.8bn).
The buyers have also committed themselves to buying out the remaining 25% of Endemol's shares, which were floated on the Dutch stock exchange in November 2005.
The owners of the publicly traded shares will be paid a price "at least equal" to what Telefonica is being paid for its 75% stake in Endemol.
Overall, the deal values Endemol at €3.5bn (£2.4bn), representing a heavy discount on the €5.5bn paid by Telefonica in 2000, at the height of the dotcom-inspired boom in media companies.
However, it marks a coup for Mr de Mol, who sold out at the height of the market and has now returned to Endemol heading the investment vehicle Cyrte.

Cyrte is one of three partners in the winning bid team, alongside Goldman Sachs and Mediacinco Catrera, and a newly incorporated entity owned by Mr Berlusconi's Mediaset and its Spanish subsidiary Telecinco.
The consortium's bid beat off rival offers fronted by Endemol's former chief operating officer, Tom Barnicoat; and the managing director of Endemol France, Stephane Courbit.
Mr Barnicoat's bid was reportedly backed by Apax Partners and US group Thomas H Lee, while a French private equity player, PAI, supported Mr Courbit.
Endemol, which was founded in 1994 by Mr de Mol and Joop van den Ende, was put up for sale by Telefonica in March.
